::: incremental
1. This session is not to **instruct** you on how you should or should not produce teaching materials.

3. We do not have all the answers to your specific needs, but we are happy to discuss and point you in the right direction.
:::

## Maths is Special {data-menu-title="Maths is Special: Equations" footer=false}
### 1. Equations
Good solution is [MathJax](https://www.mathjax.org/about) rendering of equations to HTML

::: fragment
``` tex
\begin{equation}
\int_0^\infty e^{-x^2}\,\text{d}x=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}
\end{equation}
```
:::

::: fragment
```{=tex}
\begin{equation}
\int_0^\infty e^{-x^2}\,\text{d}x=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}
\end{equation}
```
:::

::: fragment
MS Word/PowerPoint Equation Editor

- Basic equations/symbols
- Visual editor
:::

## Maths is Special {data-menu-title="Maths is Special: Handwriting" footer=false}
### 2. Handwriting
::::: columns
:::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.fragment}
#### Pros
- Authentic/Natural
- Engaging, especially when presenting
- Quicker to write
:::
::::

:::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.fragment}
#### Cons
- Legibility
- Contrast, Pixelation
- Not machine readable
:::
::::
:::::

::: {.fragment}
#### Technological Solutions

- [MathPix](https://mathpix.com/handwriting-recognition) (limited free use)
- [EquatIO](https://xerte.york.ac.uk/play.php?template_id=2036#Equatio) (licenced, expensive)
:::

## Figure Example 1: Tabsets {footer=false .smaller .scrollable}

::: panel-tabset
### Plot

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(mtcars, aes(hp, mpg)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = factor(am))) +
  geom_smooth(formula = y ~ x, method = "loess")+
  scale_color_discrete(name="Transmission", labels=c("Automatic", "Manual"))+
  labs(
    x="Power (hp)",
    y="Fuel Efficiency (mpg)",
  )
```

### Data

```{r}
knitr::kable(mtcars)
```
:::

## Figure Example 2: Interactive Widgets {footer=false}
```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-height: 5
library(leaflet)
markers <- data.frame(lat=c(52.62055711264973,-36.852),
                      lng=c(-1.1245785199624685,174.768)
                      )
leaflet() %>%
  addTiles() %>%  # Add default OpenStreetMap map tiles
  setView(lat=52.62055711264973, lng=-1.1245785199624685,zoom=17) %>%
  addMarkers(data=markers, popup=c("The home of the CAA","The birthplace of R"))
```

## Figure Example 3: Interactive Graph {footer=false .smaller}

The figure below was created using [Observable](https://prerelease.quarto.org/docs/interactive/ojs/) and [RShiny](https://prerelease.quarto.org/docs/interactive/shiny/), with [Component Layout](https://prerelease.quarto.org/docs/interactive/layout.html) to position inputs and outputs.

```{r}
ojs_define(actors = data.frame(
  x = rnorm(100),
  y = rnorm(100)
))
```

```{ojs}
//| panel: sidebar
viewof talentWeight = Inputs.range([-2, 2], { value: 0.7, step: 0.01, label: "talent weight" })
viewof looksWeight = Inputs.range([-2, 2], { value: 0.7, step: 0.01, label: "looks weight" })
viewof minimum = Inputs.range([-2, 2], { value: 1, step: 0.01, label: "min fame" })
```

```{ojs}
//| panel: fill
import { plotActors } from './actors.js';
plotActors(actors, talentWeight, looksWeight, minimum)
```

### 4. Computing
:::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
- Html documents with code blocks that can be copied
- Syntax highlighting
- Animated code blocks
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
```{.python echo=false}
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# define lists of variables
r = np.arange(0,2,0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r

# plot the function
fig, ax = plt.subplots(subplot_kw={'projection': 'polar'})
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()
```
:::

## Some Tools {footer=false}
::: {style="font-size: 0.8em;"}
- [Chirun](https://chirun.org.uk/) - conversion to multiple formats, support available
- Pandoc - conversion of existing materials
  - [Some user-friendly tools and guidance](https://xerte.york.ac.uk/play.php?template_id=2036#LaTeX)
- [R Markdown](https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/), [R Bookdown](https://bookdown.org/), [Quarto](https://quarto.org/) - frameworks for creating rich interactive notes and presentations; ideal for statistics and data analysis materials
  - [R Bookdown Example](https://twicks2011.github.io/bookdown-eg/index.html)
- [MS Office Equation Editor](https://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/office/write-an-equation-or-formula-1d01cabc-ceb1-458d-bc70-7f9737722702#category=insert_equation) - shallow learning curve and ideal for relatively simple materials
- [Jupyter Notebooks](https://jupyter.org/), [Jupyter Books](https://jupyterbook.org/) - great for notes on numerical computation or computing
  - [Jupyter Book Example](https://twicks2011.github.io/jupyter-eg/main.html#)
:::

## Existing Resources and Communities {footer=false}
:::{style="font-size:0.8em"}
- Leicester guidance from Learning Technology Team
- Colleagues!
- [University of York](https://xerte.york.ac.uk/play.php?template_id=2036#Home) (extensive advice and resources)
- [TALMO (Teaching and Learning Mathematics Online)](https://talmo.uk/index.html)
- [Bath](https://www.bath.ac.uk/projects/mathematics-accessibility/) (advice and resources, e.g. extension to R Bookdown)
- [Make Things Accessible](https://www.makethingsaccessible.com/guides/mathematical-or-discipline-specific-technical-content/) (generalist, but some maths guidance)
- Accessibility checklists, e.g.
  - [A11y](https://www.a11yproject.com/checklist/)
  - [Designing for Diverse Learners](https://designingfordiverselearners.info/)
:::
